Jan 18

The Few #1, And The Argument For The Importance of Artwork In Comics.

I’m going to be honest with you.

As much of a fan as I am of the comic book and graphic novel medium, for as long as I’ve been… the artwork as never really been “my thing.” My thing tends to be the writers; the creators. And I came to that conclusion quite accidentally, too. I would buy books from publishers I really dug (such as Avatar Press) who would continuously put out quality, mature, exciting material. And I noticed again and again “oh wow, this Warren Ellis guy writes a lot of stuff I tend to fall deeply in love with.” And then we’re off to the races, buying up everything he’s ever written. I’m a writer. I can relate to the concept of putting pen to paper with the goal of something in mind. I’m fascinated by how goddamn good these guys are at putting together scripts and dialog and worlds. All of it fascinates me. But artwork was never my deal… it always felt like a means to an end. “Well I like my words with pictures, so… cool.” I feel like you have to be artistically inclined (read: you can draw stuff) in order to really appreciate artwork of this nature, and maybe I feel like I lack that.

And then there is artwork that comes along in some books that really just blow me away. Fiona Staples does that a lot with her work in SAGA. Also Nick Dragotta’s work in EAST OF WEST. And most recently (as in today), Hayden Sherman’s work in THE FEW.

The best thing for me to do would just be to include a whole bunch of the artwork in the book for you to look at here, but just go buy the damn thing. The choices he makes; the color, and lack thereof. The minimalism. Reds, only used sparingly throughout. Playing with light and shadows. Honestly, there’s a two-page spread towards the end that I just stared at for a good ten minutes, losing myself in it and in the theme of the story.

It’s also incredibly refreshing to have such a different take with the way Sherman approaches his work; it’s not bubbly or animated by any stretch. The tone is serious; his characters are interesting and have such depth, even with the sketch-like feel. His work reminds me of the artist Derek Hess at times, who is known for doing dozens of album covers of hardcore and metal bands.

“So hey, what’s the story about Dave?”

Well honestly we don’t get much right out of the gate. The writer Sean Lewis is no slouch apparently; although I haven’t checked out his other Image book SAINTS as of yet, he’s apparently a playwright with many awards under his belt. Although post-apocalyptic fiction is all the rage nowadays, it seems like he’s zooming way in on this, while still giving us an overarching idea of what is going on with what used to be the United States. I’m giddy for more info; along with the art, Lewis takes a minimalist approach to information and dialog in this book, letting the action tell the story.

Artwork is an extremely important aspect of the comic medium, even though we tend to overlook it sometimes in favor of being fanboys over the writer/creators. Myself included. But with books like this… just, FUCK do I love this medium. Just one more example on the endless list of examples of why the comic medium is just as important and enjoyable as movies, television, and literature. Each have their strengths, and thank god for creators like Sean Lewis and Hayden Sherman for showing us why the comic medium continues to be so strong, so original, and drives much of the entertainment world today.

|DV.NWMN|
